snippet.description:

snippet.title: Drake's "Behind Barz" Explained | Song Stories
snippet.description:
Drake is back in the booth a week after the release of 'Scorpion' with bars that are sure to make major headlines.

Appearing on Link Up TV, Drake seems to be taking veiled shots at Kanye West. Though West previously said the animosity was “dead now,” Drake’s bars seem to continue the back-and-forth that began with Pusha’s “Infrared,” led to a Drake response in the form of “Duppy Freestyle” and culminated in Pusha’s “The Story of Adidon.”

snippet.title: Boogie "Self Destruction" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Compton rapper Boogie dropped his single “Self Destruction” in May as the first taste of his upcoming debut album. In 2016, after gaining buzz off his first three mixtapes, he caught Eminem’s attention and later signed to Shady Records in October 2017. Eminem says he values Boogie, the first West Coast rapper on Shady’s roster, for his “unique voice and point of view.” “Self Destruction” is co-produced by Ashton McCreight, Mario Luciano, and also Keyel, who produced a majority of Boogie’s songs to date. Eminem and Boogie previewed the song back in April on Instagram, where they also confirmed the debut album is coming this year. On the track, Boogie raps about being conscious of momentarily losing control.

snippet.title: Drake’s “In My Feelings” Explained | Song Stories
snippet.description:
Drake employs an extensive series of samples throughout his new album 'Scorpion,' including a snippet of a pop culture moment about himself. In the latest season of Donald Glover’s FX show 'Atlanta,' there’s an episode titled “Champagne Papi,” where several characters attend a part at Drake’s house in hopes of meeting him. On 'Scorpion’s' 21st track “In My Feelings,” he uses a sample of dialogue from the episode as the song’s outro. The song features production from Noah “40” Shebib, Cleveland-based TrapMoneyBenny, and New Orleans bounce producer BlaqNmilD, the latter of whom also worked on Drake’s hit single “Nice For What.”

snippet.title: All Of The Samples On Drake's 'Scorpion' | Genius News
snippet.description:
Drake’s go-to samples may be R&B classics, but the OVO rapper is also known for throwing everything from viral video clips to personal voicemails in his music. For his latest album 'Scorpion,' Drake linked up with a rolodex of producers that once again employ a wide range of unique samples from the likes of Lauryn Hill, Mariah Carey, Lil Wayne, Magnolia Shorty, and more. He also lifts vocal samples from an episode of 'Atlanta' fittingly titled “Champagne Papi,” a clip from on 'The Maury Show,' and a viral video by Florida rapper Plies.

snippet.title: Charlie Puth "The Way I Am" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
“The Way I Am" is the sixth single released from Charlie Puth’s sophomore album ‘Voicenotes,’ which peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard 200 in May. In a Beats 1 interview about the album, Puth explained that despite being the intro, “The Way I Am” was the last song he wrote for the album. He included it because the album lacked a track about his personality. Produced by Charlie Puth himself, the song has racked up 18 million Spotify streams since its release. “The Way I Am” delves into the singer’s self-realizations about his life as a celebrity.

Scott released his debut album ‘Only Human’ in March. He’s promoted four singles from the album, including “Dancing On My Own,” which grabbed the No. 2 spot on Billboard’s Official U.K. Singles Chart in 2016. snippet.title: Kendrick Lamar’s “m.A.A.d city” Explained | Song Stories Classic
snippet.description:
Kendrick Lamar’s “m.A.A.d. city” has stood the test of time and remains a fan favorite over five years after its release. The song is produced by Sounwave and T.H.C, and features the Compton rapper delving headfirst into the violent, chaotic environment he grew up in. It serves as one of the album’s two title tracks, along with “Good Kid,” and stands for both “my angry adolescence divided” and “my angels on angel dust,” both of which harken back to K-Dot’s own childhood. ScHoolboy Q and MC Eiht also lend a hand, and their combined performance helped the song achieve double-Platinum certification and reach No. 75 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

snippet.title: A Brief History Of Lil Names In Hip-Hop | Genius News
snippet.description:
“Lil” has been a commonly used prefix for rap names since the early days of hip-hop and seems to be more popular than ever. Some of the most prominent rappers of the current generation include Lil Pump, Lil Yachty, and Lil Uzi Vert. They’re the latest incarnations of the explosion in rappers with “Lil” in their name, following the rise of Lil Wayne in 1998.

snippet.title: How Drake’s ‘Scorpion’ Lyrics Address His Son | Genius News
snippet.description:
Drake’s beef with Pusha T took an unexpected turn late last month when the G.O.O.D. Music rapper claimed that Drake was “hiding a child” he conceived with French model Sophie Brussaux. The revelation brought their war of words to an immediate halt, with Drake going more or less radio silent. With his new album 'Scorpion' out, the OVO boss has finally broken his silence on the topic, admitting that he does have a son and explaining some of the reasoning behind his decision to keep the news quiet.

snippet.title: Is Drake's ‘Scorpion’ Good Or Bad? | For The Record
snippet.description:
After one of the more traditional rollouts of 2018, Drake just released his fifth studio album ‘Scorpion.’ Clocking in at nearly 90 minutes long, its 25 tracks are split into an A-side and a B-side. The project follows Drake’s 2017 playlist ‘More Life’ and features Drake finally confirming Pusha-T’s accusation of a secret child. On the latest episode of Genius’ ‘For The Record,’ Rob Markman sits down with media personality and Black Girl Podcast co-host Scottie Beam, Beats 1 host and co-founder of Dusse Palooza LowKey, and Hot 97 DJ Megan Ryte to give their thoughts on ‘Scorpion.’

snippet.title: Lil Pump, Jeezy, Migos & How Ad-Libs Took Over Hip-Hop | Genius News
snippet.description:
Over the past five years, ad-libs in hip-hop have reached such prominence that artists such as Lil Pump, Migos, and Playboi Carti have hits built around signature catchphrases. Although ad-libs are more popular than ever, their use is far from a new phenomenon. James Brown’s screams and grunts are often cited as a major inspiration for ad-libs, which were used by hype men and DJs in some of rap’s earliest recordings.

snippet.title: XXXTENTACION Has Passed Away At 20 | Genius News
snippet.description:
Florida rapper XXXTENTACION (real name Jahseh Onfroy) has died, the Broward County Sheriff’s Office confirmed. According to a report from TMZ, the 20-year-old rapper was shot while out shopping for motorcycles in Deerfield Beach, Florida. He was rushed to the hospital shortly afterwards, where he was pronounced dead.

The young MC rose to prominence in late 2016 with his breakout hit “Look At Me!.” He dropped his debut album 17 in August 2017, reaching No. 2 on the Billboard 200 albums chart. His 2018 follow-up ? (Question Mark) debuted at No. 1 and spawned the hit single “SAD!,” which reached No. 7 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. In 2017, he was the single most popular new artist on Genius, earning over 20 million pageviews across all his songs.

His popularity was met with significant controversy, as he was awaiting trial on multiple felony charges, including battery and aggravated assault of a pregnant victim, battery by strangulation, and false imprisonment. Spotify sparked industry-wide debate earlier this year after it announced that it was removing his music from editorially curated playlists due to the charges. The move was quietly reversed shortly afterwards.

Despite his disturbing personal conduct, XXX has been viewed as the most prominent voice in the emergent South Florida SoundCloud rap scene, which also includes rappers like Ski Mask The Slump God, Lil Pump, Smokepurpp, and ​​wifisfuneral. He’s collaborated with artists like Joey Bada$$, Kodak Black, Trippie Redd, Denzel Curry, and Noah Cyrus, and has been praised for his musical diversity and genre-bending work.

snippet.title: How Lil Wayne's Leaks Made 'Tha Carter III' A Hit | Genius News
snippet.description:
On 2005’s 'Tha Carter II,' Wayne proclaimed himself to be the “best rapper alive.” It may have felt lofty then, but by the end of 2007 it became the general consensus amongst rap fans and Wayne no longer had to sing his own praises. MTV crowned him the “Hottest MC In The Game,” GQ’s called him the “Workaholic of the Year,” and by 2008 Rolling Stone said he was, in fact, the “Best MC.” Going into 2008, at the height of his popularity, it was time for Wayne to deliver an album. After great anticipation, on June 10, 2008, 'Tha Carter III' was released to high praise from fans and critics alike. It sold over a million records in its first week, a fitting achievement for an album boosted by the hit single “A Milli.”

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/how-leaks-changed-lil-waynes-tha-carter-iii-and-his-career

snippet.title: Is Kanye West’s ‘ye’ Good Or Bad? | For The Record
snippet.description:
Following an elaborate listening party in rural Wyoming, Kanye West’s new album 'ye' is finally out, and it has already sparked heated debate. In light of West’s vocal support for Donald Trump and controversial comments about slavery seeming like “a choice,” some have turned their back on the musician they once loved. Others have decided to give the music a chance, but have come away from 'ye' with mixed responses.

On the latest episode of Genius' 'For the Record,' Rob Markman sits down with Hot 97’s TT Torrrez, 'BET'’s Mouse Jones, and 'Complex' and 'Pigeons & Planes‘' Brandon “Jinx” Jenkins to discuss the new project and each panelist’s current feelings about Kanye.

snippet.title: The Making Of Lil Pump's "ESSKEETIT" With CBMIX | Deconstructed
snippet.description:
Florida rapper Lil Pump and his close collaborator Smokepurpp are known for their catchphrase “Esketit!” In April, Pump flipped the ad-lib into a new song titled “ESSKEETIT” and scored his biggest hit since breaking through with “Gucci Gang.” The energetic track peaked at No. 24 on the Billboard Hot 100 and remains his second highest entry on the chart to date.

Although Lil Pump’s vocals are an important part of “ESSKEETIT,” his co-production with CBMIX sets the tone for the song. “We ran out of beats, basically, and I was like, ‘Pump, we should start making our own beats,’” CBMIX explains to Genius at the W Hotel’s Hollywood Sound Suite. “The first beat we made ended up being ‘ESSKEETIT’ and the rest is history.”

snippet.title: What Spotify's XXXTentacion & R. Kelly Ban Means For Music | For The Record
snippet.description:
On May 10, Spotify removed R. Kelly and XXXTentacion’s music from its editorial and algorithm-based playlists such as RapCaviar, Discover Weekly, and New Music Friday based on its new hate content and hateful conduct policy. According to the company, the decision was made because of each artist’s actions outside of music. In response to questions about its approach to other musicians, Spotify admitted that it is “a complicated process with room for debate” and said decisions would be made on a “case by case basis.”

snippet.title: The Making Of Chloe x Halle's "Warrior" | Deconstructed
snippet.description:
Atlanta R&B duo Chloe x Halle released their debut album 'The Kids Are Alright' in late March. One of the tracks, “Warrior,” doubles as a single from the soundtrack for the film 'A Wrinkle In Time.' It has proven to be one of their most popular songs, racking up over 1.5 million Spotify streams and 4 million YouTube views for its official music video.

Although the real-life sisters' vocals are an important part of “Warrior,” Chloe sets the tone for the song with the beat. “I think it just kind of came secondary when we were just writing our original music and our own songs,” Chloe tells Genius about learning to produce. “It was very experimental for us. We kind of just found our way by figuring it out.”

snippet.title: Will Hip-Hop's #MeToo Moment Ever Come? | Genius News
snippet.description:
Over the past year, the #MeToo movement has exposed abuses by powerful men, some of whom have committed sexual assault and other types of gender-related violence in a wide array of industries, including media, entertainment, and government. At the same time, however, men accused of physical and sexual violence against women have continued to find breakout success in hip-hop music, including XXXTENTACION, 6ix9ine, Kodak Black, and YoungBoy Never Broke Again. Hip-hop has a long history of complicity in this area, and it begs the question: will rap’s #MeToo moment ever arrive?

After releasing a handful of EPs starting in 2013, Brooklyn singer Justine Skye finally dropped her debut album 'ULTRAVIOLET' back in January. One of the standout tracks from the LP is “Don’t Think About It,” which describes spending a night with someone with no strings attached. Produced by the West London trio TMS, the song has nearly 3 million Spotify streams, and its music video has over 1 million YouTube views.

snippet.title: The Making Of J. Cole’s “ATM” Video With Director Scott Lazer | Framework
snippet.description:
Shortly after J. Cole released his most recent album ‘KOD,’ he dropped off a surreal music video for “ATM.” The self-produced song finds the North Carolina rapper addressing his complicated relationship with money. In the Scott Lazer-directed clip, Cole deals with the downsides of wealth. He’s driven mad by all his money in one scene, while another features him being robbed of large sums of cash. After losing everything while gambling, he’s forced to literally give up an arm and a leg to purchase a fancy red convertible.

snippet.title: Poo Bear On Writing For Justin Bieber & Recording ‘Bearthday Music’ | For The Record
snippet.description:
Jason Boyd, best known as Poo Bear, may not be a household name, but the four-time Grammy winner has written massive hits for the likes of Usher, 112, and Justin Bieber. After nearly two decades in the music industry, the Connecticut native recently released his debut solo album Poo Bear Presents: Bearthday Music featuring appearances from Justin Bieber, Jennifer Lopez, Ty Dolla $ign, Jay Electronica, and more. In the latest episode of Genius' For the Record, Boyd shared the process behind Bearthday Music, explained how he discovered music as a passion, and reflected upon his career as a songwriter.

snippet.title: Desiigner Talks About His New EP ‘L.O.D.’ & Working With BTS | For The Record
snippet.description:
Brooklyn rapper Desiigner skyrocketed to prominence in 2016 after his first commercial single “Panda” caught the ear of Kanye West. After signing to G.O.O.D. Music, Desiigner appeared on two tracks from Kanye’s album ‘The Life of Pablo’ including “Pt. 2,” which samples “Panda.” Thanks to the co-sign, the single reached No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 a few months later and even led to a viral lyrics video with Genius which inspired the creation of the ‘Verified’ series. Since then, Desiigner has put out a mixtape titled ‘New English,’ appeared on the G.O.O.D. Music posse cut “Champions,” and dropped a series of singles including “Tiimmy Turner” and “Up.”

snippet.description:

snippet.title: Next "Too Close" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
American R&B group Next first broke through when their debut single “Butta Love” peaked at No. 16 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in 1997. The follow-up, “Too Close,” took the trio to even greater heights, reaching No. 1 on both the Hot 100 and the R&B charts. Produced by Kay Gee, the Rated Next track would go on to top the 1998 year-end Hot 100 chart, and earn a double-Platinum certification. As Next member Raphael “Tweet” Brown points out, it’s one of the biggest hits of all time as well, sitting at No. 16 on the decade-end Hot 100 chart for 1990-1999 and No. 28 of all-time.

snippet.title: From Rakim To Drake: A History Of Arabic In Hip-Hop Lyrics | Genius News
snippet.description:
Throughout the history of hip-hop, rappers have referenced Arabic words used in Islamic prayers in their lyrics. Regardless of whether they’re Muslim or not, many MCs have invoked the words and phrases in their proper context. Many of the references include the word, Allah, the Arabic word for God. Others use the phrases “Allahu Akbar” to praise Allah and “As-Salaam-Alaikum” to indicate friendship and brotherhood. In addition, “Inshallah” is used while hoping for a good thing, while “Mashallah” thanks God for good fortune.

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/how-spiritual-arabic-sayings-appear-in-hip-hop

snippet.title: From Metro Boomin to Zaytoven: Do You Know Your Producer Tags? | Genius News
snippet.description:
Over the past few years, no hip-hop producer has become a bigger star than Metro Boomin. From releasing entire collaborative projects with 21 Savage, Offset, and Big Sean to working on singles with some of the biggest names in the game, Metro has boosted his profile considerably. It also doesn’t hurt that his beats are easily identifiable by his voice tags. One of his tags has Young Thug uttering “Metro Boomin want some more,” which you can hear on hits like Offset’s “Ric Flair Drip.” Meanwhile his “If young Metro don’t trust you, I’m gon' shoot you” tag is best exemplified on the intro of Kanye West and Kid Cudi’s 2016 hit “Father Stretch My Hands Pt. 1.” The tag is ingeniously woven into the song, serving as a crucial component of the opening drop despite previously appearing on Drake and Future’s “Jumpman” and (originally) the bridge of Uncle Murda’s “Right Now.”

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/how-voice-tags-help-hip-hop-producers-make-a-name-for-themselves

snippet.description:

snippet.title: Danny Ocean "Dembow" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Venezuelan singer-songwriter Danny Ocean became an unexpected viral sensation with “Me Rehúso” in 2016. He had just relocated to Miami to escape the economic crisis of his homeland when he created the song as a Valentine’s Day present for his girlfriend, who was still in Venezuela.

Danny’s sentimental lyrics of hope made quite an impression on listeners, as “Me Rehúso” broke the record in December for the Latin Song with the Most Weeks on Spotify’s Top 50 Global Chart. His latest self-produced song “Dembow” is proving to be his next big hit.

Blending dancehall rhythms with English and Spanish lyrics, the song taps into romantic sentiments of love at first sight. The singer tells Genius that he imagined a scenario where a man was captivated by a woman in a club, and he used the lyrics as an emotional outlet for the character.

snippet.description:

The World track “You Was Right.” The Metro Boomin-produced song was certified Platinum in March 2017, his first solo single to earn the achievement. snippet.title: The Making Of Lil Pump's "Designer" With Zaytoven | Deconstructed
snippet.description:
While Lil Pump climbed the charts last year with his breakout hit “Gucci Gang,” the official video stirred up controversy after news surfaced that it was shot in a Catholic elementary school. The Archdiocese of L.A. was furious with the school for allowing Pump to shoot a video that depicted images of drugs, and the story was picked up by broadcast news outlets.

The rapper embraced the backlash on his song “Designer,” incorporating samples from the news reports. The track dropped this past December and has since raked in over 32 million Spotify streams. The producer behind the song is noted beat-maker Zaytoven, who has also worked with everyone from Migos to Nicki Minaj to Future to Travis Scott, among others.

snippet.title: Air Max References In Hip-Hop Lyrics | Genius News
snippet.description:
In honor of Nike’s annual celebration, Air Max Day, Nike and Genius teamed up to take a look into our lyrical data to find out more about Air Max’s influence on the genre.

Ever since its inception in 1987, the Nike Air Max has become one of the most iconic sneakers of streetwear. Combining comfort and flair, its signature design of a cushioned bubble has outlasted various fashion trends over the years.
 
The Air Max has also naturally found its way into hip-hop, with KRS-One noted as one of the first rappers to reference Nike on Boogie Down Productions’ ’87 track “Dope Beat.” Since then, Air Max’s have been famously referenced by rappers like Ghostface Killah, Eminem, and Jay-Z.

snippet.title: PRhyme "Rock It" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Legendary producer DJ Premier and Detroit rapper Royce Da 5’9” returned this month with the release of ‘PRhyme 2,’ their second album under their duo moniker PRhyme. It’s the group’s first new material to surface since their self-titled debut in 2014, which received critical acclaim.

‘PRhyme 2’ was created around samples from producer AntMan Wonder’s catalog, and includes numerous features from artists like 2 Chainz, and CeeLo Green. One standout track that puts the longtime friends front and center is “Rock It.”

For the track, Premiere samples A Tribe Called Quest’s 1992 hit “Scenario.” It also interpolates Tribe’s song “Can I Kick It?” and JAY-Zs “Heart of the City (Ain’t No Love).” In an interview with Genius, Premiere explains that everything he creates is based on experimentation and that they approached “Rock It” with a live performance mentality.

Royce added that he wanted to pay homage and respect to old hip-hop tracks in the lyrics, something he says that modern rappers are afraid to do.

snippet.title: 03 Greedo Talks 2Pac, Influences & ‘The Wolf Of Grape Street’ | For The Record
snippet.description:
West Coast rapper 03 Greedo has gained momentum over the years with his three 'Purple Summer' mixtapes and breakout track “Mafia Business,” a tribute to Greedo’s friend who was killed. After inking a new deal with Alamo Records, he returned this month with his latest album 'The Wolf Of Grape Street.' The 21-track LP showcases Greedo’s woozy and melodic style matched by his signature raw lyrics.

Greedo has built a reputation for his candidness, especially when discussing his difficult upbringing of homelessness, violence, and an ear infection that resulted in partial deafness. The rapper continues the transparent dialogue in a recent in-depth conversation with Rob Markman, the host of Genius' weekly talk show 'For The Record.'

snippet.title: Berhana "Grey Luh" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Berhana first emerged on the scene in 2016 with his soulful, self-titled EP. The Atlanta-based singer garnered viral attention for his track “Janet,” an ode to actress Janet Hubert who portrayed the original Aunt Vivian on ‘The Fresh Prince.’ The song taps into melancholy sentiments and discussions surrounding colorism, while the stunning video raked in over 1 million views on YouTube.

Berhana has also seen success with his EP track “Grey Luh,” produced by his collaborator Sapphire Adizes.

The singer tells Genius that he initially wrote the chords and hook for the song while he was in school, juggling different jobs and an internship at ‘The Colbert Report.’ The lyrics reflect on being caught up in a complicated relationship, while also dealing with a state of loneliness.

snippet.title: Blac Youngsta "Booty" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Blac Youngsta has built a fanbase over the years with a slew of mixtapes and collaborations, including “Heavy” with Yo Gotti and Travis Scott’s “Coordinate.” Born Samuel Benson, the Memphis-based rapper first ignited his career in 2015 after signing to Gotti’s CMG label.

While tracks like “Tissue” have raked in millions of YouTube views, the Memphis rapper recently crossed over into mainstream success with “Booty.” Produced by Beatmonster Marc and Yung Lan, “Booty” originally appeared on his 2017 mixtape ‘I’m Innocent.’

The twerking anthem was rereleased this past February as a track on his debut studio album ‘2.23,’ and received a raunchy and comical dance video that helped grow its popularity. While “Booty” recently debuted at No. 81 on the Billboard Hot 100, Youngsta tells Genius that not everyone was initially convinced that it was a hit.

snippet.title: Fall Out Boy "Thnks fr the Mmrs" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Over the last decade, Fall Out Boy has fostered a legacy that’s become synonymous with the emo-pop scene of the early aughts. The band returned earlier this year with their seventh studio album ‘M A N I A,’ incorporating electronic sounds and lyrics filled with references to pop culture.

While Fall Out Boy has evolved through a slew of material, it’s impossible to forget where the fandom originally began. “Thnks fr th Mmrs” was one of their crossover hits, peaking at No. 11 on the Billboard Hot 100 in 2007.

Written by members Patrick Stump and Pete Wentz, the ‘Infinity On High’ track is also produced by R&B hitmaker Babyface–who worked on their song “I’m Like A Lawyer With The Way I’m Always Trying to Get You Off (Me & You),” as well. “Thnks fr th Mmrs” revolves around themes of a broken relationship but it also contains critical commentary towards society’s obsession with fame.

snippet.title: Meghan Trainor "No Excuses" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Meghan Trainor is gearing up to release to her third studio album, her first LP since 2016’s ‘Thank You.’ While the release date and official album title haven’t been revealed, the pop singer treated fans to the lead single “No Excuses” earlier this month.

The track is produced by Trainor and Andrew Wells, who has previously worked with Fall Out Boy and 5 Seconds Of Summer. In true Trainor style, “No Excuses” is an empowering anthem about treating others with respect and calls out anyone who defaults to rude behavior.

The pop singer tells Genius that she was inspired by her own personal experiences with mansplaining and disrespect, and felt that it was a timely song within the current #MeToo movement. She was also influenced by Aretha Franklin’s 1960s hit “Respect.”

snippet.title: Smooky MarGielaa "Stay '100'" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Smooky MarGielaa turned heads last year with his melodic features on A$AP Mob’s project ‘Cozy Tapes, Vol. 2: Too Cozy.’ The 15-year-old Bronx rapper kicked off his career as A$AP Rocky’s latest protégé and member of the AWGE collective.

As the son of a famous Malian singer and guitarist, Smooky naturally gravitated towards music and started rapping around 13. He’s continued to impress fans with a slew of solo singles, including the viral bop “Stay ‘100.’”

Produced by French beat-maker CashMoneyAP, the song reflects on Smooky’s newfound success and his desire to stay away from the streets. He tells Genius that he wrote the song during a trip to Los Angeles, as he reflected on all the hate he used to get before he was famous. The track also references the time he tried to sneak into Coachella with his friends.

snippet.title: Bea Miller "S.L.U.T." Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Bea Miller is best known for competing on the second season of ‘The X Factor’  back in 2012, when she was just in her teens. Although she came in ninth place on the show, the singer-songwriter made a lasting impression on fans and has since launched a recording career.

One of her standout tracks on her 2018 debut ‘Aurora’ is the body-positive anthem “S.L.U.T.,” which stands for “Sweet Little Unforgettable Thing.” The song is produced by Ido Zmishlany, who has also worked with Shawn Mendes, Demi Lovato, and Sabrina Carpenter.

“S.L.U.T.” is all about embracing self-love and empowering women. Miller tells Genius that when she was on her way to the studio to write the song, she came across a hateful and slut-shaming comment on her Instagram post that criticized her outfit. Miller decided to flip the negativity into a positive sentiment, giving new meaning to the derogatory word.

snippet.description:
Doobie is a rising rapper who prides himself on keeping it real and transparent in his lyrics. The Columbus, Ohio native cultivated a grassroots fanbase with tracks like “Hopeless,” fusing hip-hop styles with guitar melodies.

Doobie (real name Eric Williams) reached a new level of fame with “When The Drugs Don’t Work,” a raw and honest track about the rapper’s drug use.

He created the self-produced song after finishing a tour, and set a goal to write provocative lyrics that fans would remember. The song also references music legend Kurt Cobain, who Doobie admires, and calls out anyone who wears a rock t-shirt without knowing the band’s music.

snippet.title: SOB X RBE "Paramedic!" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Rap group SOB X RBE have been crafting music since their early teens, and their hard work has paid off. The Vallejo, California group built a strong local fanbase that expanded with the release of viral tracks like “Anti” and “Different.”

Now an established quartet (Yhung T.O., Slimmy B, DaBoii, and Lul G), SOB recently received a huge boost for their 'Black Panther: The Album' track “Paramedic!.” The song is produced by Sounwave, CuBeatz and DJ Dahi, and also features Zacari and Kendrick Lamar--who served as an executive producer on the album inspired by the Marvel film.

SOB keeps it real on the hard-hitting track as they reflect on their lives growing up and dare anyone to challenge their bars. The group tells Genius that they wanted to provide real rap and metaphors that everyone can relate to.

snippet.title: How “Type Beats” Have Changed Hip-Hop Production | Genius News
snippet.description:
Sha Money XL, the veteran producer and A&R, still remembers finding the instrumental for The Game’s smash single “Hate It or Love It” nearly 15 years ago. “I used to go through thousands of various producers' CD submissions, find the best ones, and give them to my artist,” he recalls. After listening to an untold number of demos, while flipping through a disc from Cool & Dre, Sha came across the “Hate It or Love It” beat.

snippet.title: Tory Lanez "Hate To Say" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Tory Lanez returned this month with his highly anticipated sophomore release 'Memories Don’t Die'. The album is heavily inspired by Lanez’s real-life experiences and reflects on both the good and bad from his past.

This narrative is especially seen on the provocative track “Hate To Say,” an explosive song that addresses his numerous beefs over the years with artists like Drake and Travis Scott. Lanez linked up with producers Christian Lou, Bobby Made The Beat, and Play Picasso for the song, and it also surprisingly samples One Direction’s “You & I.”

Lanez doesn’t hold back with delivering the shots, but he reassures us that some of the problems have been since squashed. While the lyrics are full of confident lines, he makes it clear that he’s worked hard for his success.

snippet.title: Lauv "I Like Me Better" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
Lauv is a rising singer-songwriter who first caught attention for his 2015 love-sick single “The Other.” Born as Ari Staprans Leff in San Francisco, he started writing songs in his early teens and harnessed his skills in a music technology program at New York University.

He released his biggest hit “I Like Me Better” last year, which received a sentimental official video that raked in over 18 million YouTube views. “I Like Me Better” was self-produced and written in his bedroom. It was inspired by his real-life experience of falling in love for the first time while attending NYU. With a fresh sound that mixes old-school soul vocals and R&B beats, the Colombian singer caught the attention of hip-hop artists such as Snoop Dogg and Tyler, The Creator. Uchis has since built a resume of additional collaborations with Tyler, Miguel, and Latin music superstar Juanes. She also grabbed her first Grammy nomination this year for Best R&B Performance, as a feature on Daniel Caesar’s track “Get You.”

Uchis' latest hit is the retro-sounding and smooth single “After The Storm,” featuring Tyler and funk legend Bootsy Collins. Racking in over 6 million streams on YouTube, the song tackles themes of survival and inner conflict. Uchis also references her own personal difficulties of living U.S., far away from her Colombian family members.

snippet.title: Lyrics To Life Brought To You By Genius & Dropbox | Genius News
snippet.description:
Genius' mission has always been to reveal the deeper meaning behind songs. Now those interpretations will be explored in Lyrics to Life, an immersive visual art event presented by Genius and Dropbox. The event will feature original installations that are inspired by some of the most notable song lyrics across different genres.

Rapper Aminé will display artwork based on his own song “Turf” and its lyrics about his life growing up in Portland.

The event will also feature visionary L.A-based artist Devin Troy Strother’s work inspired by The Weeknd’s hit song “The Hills," as he explores the concept “Who are we to judge?”

Marina Fini, who’s known for her colorful plexiglass exhibits, will display her work that brings Radiohead’s popular 1993 single “Creep” to life.

Other artists will be creating series of living artworks that interpret songs by Tame Impala, Nicki Minaj, Sia, and Animal Collective.

Lyrics to Life will take place through March 2-5, in the L.A. Arts District. Tickets will go on sale February 8.

Check out the video above to learn more about Lyrics to Life and RSVP for the event right here: http://lyricstolife.genius.com/

snippet.title: A History of JAY-Z's Grammy Award Snubs | Genius News
snippet.description:
On Sunday, JAY-Z attended the 60th annual Grammy Awards leading the nominations with eight possible wins. However, he left the celebration without a single trophy—and it wasn’t the first time. Despite earning 21 Grammy’s, the Brooklyn native’s been nominated 74 times and often lauded for his guest appearances on other artists’ songs like Beyonce’s “Crazy In Love” or Lil Wayne’s “Mr. Carter,” rather than his own tracks or albums like “Family Feud” or '4:44.'

snippet.title: Drake's "Diplomatic Immunity" References, Explained | Genius News
snippet.description:
Drake’s new song “Diplomatic Immunity” first grabbed headlines for its references to Jennifer Lopez, Joe Budden, and Wu-Tang Clan, but there’s also a curious bit of European history buried in it. On the Nick Brongers and Boi-1da-produced track, Drake drops a reference to the Treaty of Versailles, which was signed by the warring nations of Europe to establish peace after World War I. On its surface, the line is meant as a warning to Drake’s rivals that he’s not afraid to violate a truce that doesn’t benefit him.

snippet.title: Here’s What Every Producer Needs To Know To Get Paid | Genius News
snippet.description:
Earlier this month, Pittsburg producer E. Dan made claims on Twitter that Atlantic Records paid him only half of his normal rate for his work on Wiz Khalifa’s 2016 album, 'Khalifa,' because it was classified as a mixtape. His revelation sparked conversations with other producers who aired their frustrations concerning royalties and payments from labels. This includes producer TM88 who tweeted that he was never paid for Lil Uzi Vert’s hit single, “XO TOUR Llif3.”

According to an entertainment lawyer we interviewed, a major form of income for producers often comes from royalty advances, however, that’s not always plausible because mixtapes don’t usually have the same budgets as albums. Navigating producer deals and rates can seem overwhelmingly complex, but there are guidelines to follow. Check out the video above to learn how producers can protect their paychecks.

snippet.title: The Impact of Mariah Carey's "All I Want for Christmas Is You" | Genius News
snippet.description:
“All I Want for Christmas Is You” allegedly began with a disagreement between Mariah Carey and her ex-husband and then-Sony Music head Tommy Mottola—he wanted the songstress to record a holiday album and she thought she was too young. With three albums under her belt at that point, 'Mariah Carey,' 'Emotions' and 'Music Box,' she wasn’t a legacy artist just yet. But time would prove Mottola’s intuition correct. Carey’s 1994 'Merry Christmas' album has become a seasonal mainstay and few holiday parties—or Billboard charts—would be right without it. Not bad for a rumored 15 minutes of work from the elusive chanteuse and the song’s co-writer, Walter Afanasieff.

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/behind-mariah-carey-s-all-i-want-for-christmas-is-you

snippet.title: The Making Of Drake's "The Motto" With T-Minus | Deconstructed
snippet.description:
Drake’s 2011 song “The Motto” featuring Lil Wayne remains a fan favorite more than five years after it was first released. Beyond catapulting the phrase “YOLO” into the stratosphere, “The Motto” stands as one of the biggest hits from the OVO boss' sophomore album 'Take Care.' It’s produced by T-Minus, who also worked on the 'Take Care' songs “HYFR” and “Under Ground Kings,” and later linked up with Drake for the 'More Life' cuts “Blem” and “Sacrifices.”

snippet.title: What The “Mumble Rap” Debate Means For Hip-Hop | Genius News
snippet.description:
There is perhaps no issue in 2017 hip-hop more divisive than the merits of so-called “mumble rap.” The term, which is now applied to a wide swath of new artists with different styles, originated as a way to describe artists like Future and Young Thug, whose lyrics are often initially tough to decipher. However, the tradition of focusing on melody and flow over lyrical articulation goes back much further to artists like Bone Thugs-n-Harmony, Ol' Dirty Bastard, and more. Today, “mumble rappers” like Lil Uzi Vert, 21 Savage, and the aforementioned Future rule the charts, and even traditional MCs are taking notice, for better or for worse.

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/breaking-down-the-origins-of-mumble-rap

snippet.title: The Evolution of Gucci Mane | Rewind
snippet.description:
Atlanta legend Gucci Mane has been one of the hardest working rappers for years. Born in Bessemer, Ala., Gucci moved to Atlanta when he was nine years old, and started writing raps in 2001 after he was arrested for the first time. He first broke out in the mid-2000s with innovative trap hits like “Icy” and “Pillz.” After getting out of jail in 2009, Gucci grabbed his first Gold single with “Wasted,” which appeared on his first Gold album 'The State Vs. Radric Davis.' He continued to pump out hits, including the ubiquitous “Lemonade,” before going back to jail in 2014. Since then, he’s been sober and releasing the best music of his career. He even scored a No. 1 hit with Rae Sremmurd’s “Black Beatles.”

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/rewind-the-evolution-of-gucci-mane

snippet.title: Remembering Lil Peep’s Most Memorable Lyrics | Genius News
snippet.description:
Rapper Lil Peep (real name Gustav Åhr) has passed away at 21, multiple reports have confirmed. Peep was known for his distinct style blending rock and hip-hop music, and he often rapped about drug use and depression. Many of his biggest songs include frank discussions of death, and he was frequently classified as “emo rap.” He gained popularity primarily through SoundCloud, where he amassed over 300,000 followers and tallied millions of streams on his biggest tracks. In honor of Peep's work, Genius takes a look back at some of his most memorable lyrics.

snippet.title: Is Eminem Teasing His New Album With This “Revival” Drug? | Genius News
snippet.description:
On Wednesday, Eminem’s manager and co-founder of Shady Records Paul Rosenberg Instagramed a photo of Yelawolf’s album, ‘Trial By Fire,’ which drops Friday. In the photo, behind the actual album, there’s a billboard ad for something called Revival. 

The billboard looks like a typical prescription drug ad but fans on Reddit noticed something else in the photo that most people would miss: The E in Revival is backwards—just like in Eminem’s logo.
This, of course, led to fans finding the website AskAboutRevival.com. Not only is the website registered to Interscope Records, but it’s filled with hints that it’s both a fake website and likely the name of Eminem’s newest album. Check out the Genius video above that breaks it all down.

snippet.title: Deconstructing Inspectah Deck's Verse On Wu-Tang Clan's "Triumph" | Check The Rhyme
snippet.description:
Back in 1997, Wu-Tang Clan dropped “Triumph” as the lead single for their sophomore album Wu-Tang Forever. The track features all nine members of Wu-Tang Clan plus Cappadonna, and it (along with its famous, Brett Ratner-directed video) remains a high point in the group’s catalog. The RZA-produced “Triumph” kicks off with an iconic verse from Inspectah Deck, featuring a complex rhyme scheme that is often cited as one of the best rap verses of all time.

U.K. rapper Scarlxrd was previously in the rap-rock band Myth City, before he broke out and created his current rap moniker. After stepping out on his own, he released his first of seven mixtapes in 2016. All of that momentum brings him to his new track “6 Feet,” off of his latest project 'Lxrdszn.' The song has only been online for one month, yet already has over 654,000 Spotify streams and an additional 594,000 plays on Soundcloud. The Muppy-produced track is Scarlxrd at his darkest moment, using music as an escape from his personal struggles.

snippet.title: Bad Bunny, Messiah & Ozuna Are Making Latin Trap Music The Hottest New Sound
snippet.description:
There’s no question that Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee’s “Despacito” ruled summer 2017 and  Colombian reggaeton singer J Balvin saw his song “Mi Gente” rise to the No. 1 spot on Spotify’s Global Top 50 playlist in August. Meanwhile, a new subgenre called Latin trap—which is built on the sound of Southern U.S. trap music—is gaining traction fast on both Spotify and YouTube. It’s led by the ascension of Bad Bunny, whose “Soy Peor” has over 300 million views on YouTube and 75 million streams on Spotify. Check out the Genius video above that highlights some of the rising stars in Latin Trap.

snippet.title: Can Migos & YouTube Stars Save TRL? | Genius News
snippet.description:
MTV is reviving 'Total Request Live,' the daily music countdown show that served as a millennial version of 'American Bandstand.' It’s a huge bet for MTV, but will it work? TRL certainly evokes a lot of nostalgia, but much has changed since it debuted 20 years ago. 'Total Request Live’s' first episode aired in 1998 and was hosted by Carson Daly. It slotted music videos into a daily countdown by tallying votes from callers at home. We won’t know the verdict on the new 'TRL' for awhile, but for now let’s revel in some pop culture nostalgia of the 2000s in the Genius video above.

snippet.title: Why Anger Over The National Anthem Is Nothing New In America | Genius News
snippet.description:
Over the weekend, almost every NFL team took part in protesting police brutality and the treatment of African Americans in the United States by kneeling or locking arms during the National Anthem, a movement that was originally sparked by former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick in 2016.

Many of the players were audibly booed for their actions, which some see as unpatriotic and disrespectful to the armed forces. However, this isn’t the first time people have caught feelings over the “Star Spangled Banner.” Genius breaks down the history of moments when celebrities have experienced backlash behind their renditions of the National Anthem in the video above.

snippet.title: The Evolution Of Lil Wayne | Rewind
snippet.description:
Lil Wayne has been rapping since he was a child and worked his way to the top of the charts. The New Orleans MC got his first taste of stardom as a member of the Hot Boys, with their successful 1997 album 'Get It How U Live.' From there came his multi-Platinum debut album 'Tha Block Is Hot,' opening the door for other successful projects like '500 Degreez' and 'Tha Carter II.' He is the heart and soul of Young Money, the collective that birthed both Nicki Minaj and Drake’s record-breaking careers. Wayne also had his share of dust-ups, even ending up locked in a legal battle with Birdman, the same person who gave him his first real shot as a rapper.

The music of reggae legend Sister Nancy has played a pivotal role in hip-hop for over 30 years, but she’s rarely seen profits from her influence. Recently, JAY-Z sampled Nancy’s “Bam Bam” for his track “Bam,” the same song Kanye West reworked for his 'The Life of Pablo' cut “Famous.” Genius decided to trace the song’s evolution from a local hit to a frequently-sampled component of hip-hop.

snippet.title: The History of Rappers & Cartoons | Genius News
snippet.description:
Cartoons, like rap, are expressions of art. It’s no surprise that rappers have made been lending their voices (and likenesses) to popular cartoons for such a long time. Whether it’s ‘90s duo Kid ‘n Play having their own animated show, or 50 Cent asking Bart Simpson to join him on a world tour, rappers have been intertwined with cartoons for decades. The early embrace of rappers by cartoonists has paved the way for modern times, when your favorite artist can easily appear on your most beloved animated show. Genius looked at the long and storied history of rappers and cartoons, from then to now.

She left Canada for Miami after graduating, only to come home and pursue her dreams in 2014. This lead to her releasing the song “Figures” in 2016, which is currently at 16 million streams and counting on Spotify and 334,000 Soundcloud plays. “Figures” centers a heartbroken Reyez, wishing she could feel less embarrassed about dedicating herself to an untrustworthy lover.

snippet.title: How Chopped & Pitched Vocals Took Over Pop Music
snippet.description:
Technology has always been an important part of music’s evolution. In modern music, producers are using programs to cut vocal samples from existing songs and altering their pitch to create something new. Huge hits such as Major Lazer’s “Lean On” and The Chainsmokers' “Closer” are recent examples of this decades-old process. To put it into perspective, Genius laid out how this strategy became integral to many of pop’s most successful songs.

snippet.title: East Coast Rappers Ruled 2017 By Finally Embracing The South | Genius News
snippet.description:
For the last five years, the East Coast has experienced a growing trend. From 2011-2016, up-and-coming artists became breakout stars by creating major hits; A$AP Rocky’s “Purple Swag,” Bobby Shmurda’s “Hot Nigga,” Fetty Wap’s “Trap Queen,” Desiigner’s “Panda,” and Young M.A’s “Ooouuu.” Although all those artists hail from the Tri-State area, all of those songs are approximations of regional sub genres—Houston’s “chopped and screwed,” Chicago’s “drill,” and Atlanta’s “trap”—repackaged for worldwide consumption. Those songs would go platinum multiple times over, rule the Billboard charts, and/or net each rapper a lucrative record deal. The path those artists took used to be the exception, but it’s now the rule.

snippet.title: A Comprehensive Timeline Of Kanye West & Kid Cudi’s Rocky Relationship | Genius News
snippet.description:

Music associates shared photos of the encounter using the hashtag #EverybodyWins and teasing a December 31 release date, prompting speculation that the two rappers were working on new music together.

The two rappers have been collaborating for nearly a decade, starting with ‘Ye’s groundbreaking 2008 album '808’s & Heartbreak.' Cudi has appeared on every Kanye West album since, and Kanye was also featured on Cudi’s first two albums. The Cleveland rapper left G.O.O.D. Music in 2013 and distanced himself from Kanye for several years before reuniting with his former mentor in 2016.

snippet.title: The History Of Sound Clash Culture
snippet.description:
With Culture Clash coming up next week in Atlanta, Genius decided to look back at the origins and legacy of sound clash events in collaboration with Red Bull. A sound clash is a musical competition that first originated in the streets of Kingston, Jamaica in the late 1950s. Evolving from rag-tag sound system assemblies blasting out of cars into the organized and marketed events of today, sound clash has a rich musical legacy. Jamaicans brought the culture with them around the globe, influencing music in the U.S., U.K., Japan, and Europe. Even hip-hop founding father DJ Kool Herc cited sound clash as a major influence on the development of rap music.

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/the-history-of-sound-clash-culture

snippet.title: Busta Rhymes' "Dangerous" Was Inspired By An Anti-Drug PSA | Genius News
snippet.description:
Busta Rhymes‘ 1998 track “Dangerous” doesn’t seem like it carries a strong drug safety message, but the song’s chorus traces its roots to some unique source material. Busta borrows the lyrics from a 1980s anti-drug PSA that warns children about the dangers of taking prescription medication unsupervised. The Rashad Smith-produced track peaked at No. 8 on the Billboard Hot 100—marking one of the highest-charting solo hits of Busta’s career—and was eventually certified Gold.

snippet.title: How The Hebrew Israelites Influence Kendrick Lamar and Kodak Black | Genius News
snippet.description:
Kendrick Lamar dropped his fourth studio album DAMN. back in April, and attentive fans may have caught a new reference in the rapper’s dense and allusive rhymes.

Kendrick is referencing the book of Deuteronomy in the Bible, where Moses addresses the Twelve Tribes of Israel who have made their exodus from slavery in Egypt and wandered for 40 years in the desert. The Israelites are about to enter the land promised to them by God, and Moses gives them God’s holy law and warns of dire consequences should they break it.

Kendrick’s lyrics often delve into spiritual territory, but the Old Testament fire and brimstone is a new theme for him. Perhaps disillusioned by what many see as a dark turn in the country’s history, he is searching for roots by referencing the teachings of the Hebrew Israelites, a black religious movement that has thrived on the margins of the country’s spiritual landscape for over a century.

Lamar is not alone. Two months after the release of DAMN., Kodak Black echoed Kendrick’s lines on “First Day Out,” the first single he dropped after being released from prison.

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/inside-the-hebrew-israelite-movement-that-s-inspiring-kendrick-lamar-kodak-black

snippet.title: Tracking The Many Voices Of Kendrick Lamar | Genius News
snippet.description:
A big part of Kendrick Lamar’s music is his rotating series of voices. From one track to the next, Kendrick can jump from a high-pitched squeal to a syrupy drawl to a rapid-fire patter, coloring his songs with new feeling every time he switches his tone. The Compton rapper has discussed several of these voices throughout his career, including his “Lord of the Rings” voice and his “Gemini alter-ego.” Genius explored some of his most common voices to understand how he uses vocal tone and inflection to tell stories and convey emotion in his music.

snippet.title: The History Of Auto-Tune | Genius News
snippet.description:
Since its development in 1997, Auto-Tune has made its way into almost every genre of music. While the talkbox and vocoder give songs a retro feel, Auto-Tune was originally used on futuristic pop hits. In 1998, Cher’s “Believe” was one of the first commercial recordings to use the effect. In 1999 Jennifer Lopez released her No. 1 hit “If You Had My Love.” Inspired by J. Lo, T-Pain took Auto-Tune to the next level.

On his 2005 debut, T-Pain used it to distort his vocals, rather than just pitch-correct them. In 2007, Snoop Dogg embraced the effect on “Sexual Eruption.” In 2008, Lil Wayne adopted the technique for 'Tha Carter III.' Later that year, Kanye dropped his Auto-Tuned '808s & Heartbreak.' But then in 2009, JAY-Z announced his desire to kill the effect with “D.O.A. (Death Of Auto-Tune).” Since then, there have been protests… but the effect has persevered.

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/the-history-of-auto-tune

snippet.title: 2 Chainz On His 'Statue of Liberty of Atlanta' Trap House
snippet.description:
2 Chainz stopped by Genius HQ in Brooklyn earlier this week for a candid conversation about the state of trap and his new album 'Pretty Girls Like Trap Music.' He broke down what inspired the cover art for his album and why he decided to bring it to life with his wildly popular pink trap house in Atlanta. “I wanted it to still be a bando, I wanted it to look like a trap house,” he said. “But I want it to be pretty and they was looking just like you. So I rolled around, me and Tech rolled around and we took pictures of houses in some neighborhoods of Atlanta. And I was originally going to do some post color correction… I just pitched the whole idea about a pink trap house painting, like art. And it worked out and that’s how we have everything.”

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/2-chainz-broke-down-how-his-drake-collab-big-amount-came-together

snippet.title: Deconstructing Lupe Fiasco's "Touch The Sky" Verse | Check The Rhyme
snippet.description:
“Touch the Sky” was the fourth single released from Kanye West’s 2005 album 'Late Registration,' following “Diamonds from Sierra Leone,” “Gold Digger,” and “Heard ‘Em Say,” and is one of West’s most iconic songs. It’s produced by Just Blaze and features a slowed down horn sample from Curtis Mayfield’s “Move On Up” plus a stellar feature verse from fellow Chicago MC Lupe Fiasco. The show-stopping verse marked Lupe’s first credit on a studio album and features his trademark lyricism and intricate rhyme scheme.

Check out Genius contributor @JohnCLE71’s color-coded breakdown of Lupe’s rhyme scheme on the song’s third verse.

snippet.title: The Evolution Of 50 Cent | Rewind
snippet.description:
50 Cent has been a huge presence in hip-hop for years. The Jamaica, Queens native first burst onto the scene in the late ‘90s after learning the ropes from the legendary Jam Master Jay. Soon after, he was dropping acclaimed mixtapes like '50 Cent is the Future' and 'No Mercy, No Fear' that eventually gave way to multi-Platinum albums like 'Get Rich or Die Tryin'' and 'The Massacre.' Along the way, he formed his G-Unit collective alongside Tony Yayo, Young Buck, and Lloyd Banks, and participated in a revolving series of beefs with rappers like Ja Rule, The Game, and Rick Ross.

snippet.title: Shakespeare References in Rap Lyrics: An Animated History
snippet.description:
Leading up to the premiere of its new series Will, TNT teamed up with Genius to present some of the best Shakespeare references in rap.

Though Shakespeare and hip-hop have a long history, certain artists have referenced the bard more than others. Most recently, JAY-Z quoted Hamlet on “Marcy Me” off of his latest album, '4:44.'

But the Brooklyn rapper’s affinity for Shakespeare goes back further than this, with a Macbeth reference on 2006’s “Do U Wanna Ride” and a Julius Caesar reference on 2013’s “FuckWithMeYouKnowIGotIt.”

Check the video above for a full breakdown of rap’s best Shakespeare shout outs from A Tribe Called Quest, Danny Brown, Biz Markie, 2Pac, and more. Tune in to Will on July 10, 2017 on TNT.

Mobb Deep member Prodigy passed away this week at 42 years old. In honor of the rapper who put his lifetime in between the paper’s lines, Genius rounded up some of his most infamous lyrics.

snippet.title: French Montana "Unforgettable" Official Lyrics & Meaning | Verified
snippet.description:
French Montana celebrated his 32th birthday by dropping the Swae Lee-featuring summer smash “Unforgettable.” The song is currently sitting at No. 17 on the Billboard Hot 100 and No. 24 on the Genius Top Songs Chart. For French, the song came together immediately and was a “marriage between the beat, the culture, the sound.”

Read more on Genius: https://genius.com/a/french-montana-breaks-down-unforgettable-on-genius-video-series-verified
